quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If you were the CEO of this company, would you fully fund your own team? Frankly, most of the people I ask that question to don't know the answer right away.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A career-saving self-audit question to pressure-test whether your team is truly delivering CEO-level value.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Even if you are told to build the thing that the execs are really excited about, you're still going to get fired eventually.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A contrarian warning that “executive excitement” isn’t a substitute for durable business impact.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It starts with adding little features here and there, making little cosmetic improvements until the next round of layoffs.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A concise description of the low-impact trap teams fall into when they optimize for output over outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So the first is in setting team goals, no more than one step away from company goals. Don't let it get cascaded into oblivion.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for keeping team goals tightly coupled to company outcomes to avoid diluted, low-impact work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: You can follow all the best practices, but if your company goes out of business, they're not going to keep writing your paycheck for two years because all of your OKRs were a 0. 6 or a 0.7.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that process metrics and “good OKR hygiene” don’t matter if the business outcomes aren’t there.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Enterpret unifies all customer conversations in real time, from Gong recordings to Zendesk tickets to Twitter threads, and makes it available for your team for analysis and for action.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Enterpret)
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable approach to centralizing multi-channel customer feedback so teams can analyze and act on it quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What makes Enterpret unique is its ability to build and update a customer-specific knowledge graph that provides the most granular and accurate categorization of all customer feedback, and connects that customer feedback to critical metrics like Revenue and CSAT.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Enterpret)
quotes.context: Introduces a methodology for structuring feedback (knowledge graph) and tying it directly to business outcomes (Revenue, CSAT).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If modernizing your voice of customer program to a generational upgrade is a 2025 priority, like customer-centric industry leaders like Canva, Notion, Perplexity, and Linear, reach out to the team at interpret.com/Lenny.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Enterpret)
quotes.context: Frames VoC modernization as a strategic priority and grounds it with specific examples of companies associated with the approach.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: On October 16th, join thousands of product managers, marketers, and leaders for free virtual experience built to tackle today's toughest challenges and explore the future of product.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Pragmatic Institute)
quotes.context: Provides a concrete, time-bound opportunity for practitioners to learn and benchmark against a large peer group.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Whether you're building products, leading teams, or leveling up your career, this summit delivers practical insights designed to move your team forward.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Pragmatic Institute)
quotes.context: Emphasizes applying learnings to execution and team progress rather than purely theoretical content.

quotes.topic_title: Matt’s music background and product parallels
quotes.text: The magic lies in the way people work together. That's really what I think has been the consistent thread between all the work that I've done.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A simple guiding principle that frames both music and product success as fundamentally collaborative, not individual.

quotes.topic_title: Matt’s music background and product parallels
quotes.text: And it's that magic of people with different perspectives, different ideas, building into something that is somehow greater than the sum of its individual parts and perspectives.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A mental model for why diverse teams outperform: the goal is emergent outcomes, not additive contributions.

quotes.topic_title: Matt’s music background and product parallels
quotes.text: When people have the opportunity to, I think, close themselves off from the messier parts of human interaction, from those moments where you realize that your perspective might be limited, that somebody else might be able to expose you to something, show you a way of working, show you a way of seeing that you haven't seen before, I think that those interactions, that ability to learn from and build with each other, is only going to become more valuable and more precious, frankly, as technology continues to do what technology does.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A counterintuitive AI-era takeaway: as tech reduces friction, deliberately leaning into human messiness becomes a competitive advantage.

quotes.topic_title: Why impact-first: aligning to business outcomes
quotes.text: It's important because at the end of the day, it is those business critical outcomes against which you and your team will be evaluated. That's the reality of working for a business, right?
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A blunt mental model for prioritization: teams should optimize for the outcomes they’ll actually be judged on.

quotes.topic_title: Why impact-first: aligning to business outcomes
quotes.text: If you are contributing to the business in a way that the business at large can understand, that the CEO can understand, that the CFO can understand, if your team is a good investment for the business, then the business will continue making that investment.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to translate product work into executive/finance language so it’s legible as an investment.

quotes.topic_title: Why impact-first: aligning to business outcomes
quotes.text: If your team is not a good investment for the business or you don't really know if your team is a good investment for the business, but you figure you're showing up, so probably it's fine, you guess, then that puts you in a really tenuous position, and a position that I think we've all seen not work out terribly well for everybody in recent history.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that “being busy” or “showing up” isn’t a safety net unless you can prove ROI.

quotes.topic_title: Why impact-first: aligning to business outcomes
quotes.text: The message that Daniel Ek from Spotify sent out with their layoffs in 2024 said, "We still have too many teams doing work around the work and supporting work, rather than focusing on opportunities with real impact."
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A concrete example from a CEO explaining layoffs in terms of impact vs. “work around the work.”

quotes.topic_title: Why impact-first: aligning to business outcomes
quotes.text: I think we are in a moment where it is really incumbent upon each product team and each member of each product team to be able to understand, articulate, and work towards the top line business impact of their own work.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A practical call-to-action: every team member should be able to explain and drive top-line impact, not just build features.

quotes.topic_title: Impact on resumes and credit-taking dynamics
quotes.text: Awesome. So where this comes from is, one, if you are not driving something that is directly driving business growth, you're not as valuable to the company. You're the kind of person that they'd lay off.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A blunt, actionable framing that ties product work to business growth as a key lever for job security.

quotes.topic_title: Impact on resumes and credit-taking dynamics
quotes.text: Absolutely. Yeah. I mean, it's the most common resume advice I see, is show the number, show the impact, say what you did.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Direct resume guidance: quantify outcomes and clearly state ownership to improve hiring outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Impact on resumes and credit-taking dynamics
quotes.text: And she said, "I love your resume except for one thing. Why do you write like a little girl? Say what you did, say what your contributions were. Don't say 'I helped. I may have maybe helped people do this'. Say the impact. Put the number on it."
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A memorable example showing how hedging language hides impact—and how to rewrite bullets to be specific and measurable.

quotes.topic_title: Impact on resumes and credit-taking dynamics
quotes.text: It's really hard to say, "Well, I did this and I contributed to that," but that's part of why I wrote this book at the team level, because I think for folks, like myself, who really enjoy and thrive in that team environment, if you can look at the product team as the foundational unit of impact and say, "We delivered this. We were able to work together to have this impact for the business," that feels really good and also speaks directly to the work that that team did together.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A practical mental model for credit-taking: frame measurable outcomes at the team level to stay collaborative while still demonstrating impact.

quotes.topic_title: The CEO funding question as a reality check
quotes.text: So the first question I ask most of the teams I work with is if you were the CEO of this company, would you fully fund your own team?
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Introduces a simple but powerful stress-test question to evaluate a team’s perceived ROI and strategic necessity.

quotes.topic_title: The CEO funding question as a reality check
quotes.text: So I like asking this question because it's a perspective shift. It gets you thinking if you were personally accountable for the existential market-level success of this business, would you invest in your team?
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Reframes product work from feature delivery to CEO-level accountability for business survival and investment decisions.

quotes.topic_title: The CEO funding question as a reality check
quotes.text: And again, to me that is a risky situation to be in because if you can't answer that question as a member of the team, nobody else in the organization is going to be as well-equipped to answer that question as you are.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Warns that ambiguity about a team’s value is dangerous because the team itself is best positioned to justify its existence.

quotes.topic_title: The CEO funding question as a reality check
quotes.text: So bringing that question to the team, asking it and answering it proactively and collaboratively and being ready to say, "Okay, if we can't answer this confidently, what are the changes we need to make? Do we need to change our purview? Do we need to change our goals? Who do we need to talk to? What do we need to do in order to make this happen, in order to answer that question confidently?" We are much better off having that conversation at the team level than waiting for someone else to have it for us, or at us.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, proactive playbook for aligning scope, goals, and stakeholders before leadership forces the conversation.

quotes.topic_title: PM as mini-CEO, but for the whole team
quotes.text: I think the way I've come to think about it is that the product manager is responsible for the whole team thinking like a CEO, if that makes sense.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Reframes the “mini-CEO PM” idea as an enabling role that elevates commercial thinking across the entire team.

quotes.topic_title: PM as mini-CEO, but for the whole team
quotes.text: So if the product manager takes that on as their sole responsibility and says, "I'm the mini CEO. I think about the business," that's a missed opportunity.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Warns that treating business thinking as the PM’s exclusive domain limits team impact and learning.

quotes.topic_title: PM as mini-CEO, but for the whole team
quotes.text: In my consulting work, it's more often than not been an engineer who's actually able to get to that specific impact-level goal for the team, sometimes before the product manager does, because the engineer is thinking in systems, is thinking about, "Okay, I know this system, I know this other system. I've had this conversation with this person. I think I see how this can all fit together."
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Concrete example that engineers can surface impact-level goals first when empowered, challenging PM-centric assumptions.

quotes.topic_title: PM as mini-CEO, but for the whole team
quotes.text: So I think the way that I certainly initially misinterpreted the mini CEO thing was you are solely in charge of this, as opposed to you are the person who brings that kind of CEO-level commercial thinking to the team. And I've been much more inclined of late to see the product manager's job as to bring in and facilitate that conversation, rather than to be the sole owner of that conversation.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Offers an actionable shift: PMs should facilitate CEO-level commercial conversations rather than own them alone.

quotes.topic_title: What businesses expect: value exchange and context
quotes.text: My favorite definition of product management comes from Melissa Perry's book Escaping the Build Trap, where she describes product management as facilitating a value exchange.You're facilitating a value exchange between a business and its customers.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Provides a clear, portable mental model for product management centered on value exchange rather than outputs.

quotes.topic_title: What businesses expect: value exchange and context
quotes.text: The actual shape and nature of that value exchange depends on so many things. It depends on your funding model, it depends on your business model, it depends on whether you're B2B or B2C, it depends on whether you're publicly traded or privately held.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Emphasizes that “good product” is context-dependent and should be tailored to the company’s constraints and incentives.

quotes.topic_title: What businesses expect: value exchange and context
quotes.text: I think that the best product managers and teams I've worked with are really curious to understand what success means to their particular business.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: explicitly define business success in your environment before deciding what to build.

quotes.topic_title: What businesses expect: value exchange and context
quotes.text: So if that's a startup, how much runway do we have? What do we need to raise that next round? Are our investors looking for growth? Are they looking for profitability? What are they looking for in order for us to reach that next existential milestone?
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Offers a practical checklist of questions PMs can use to align product work to startup survival and funding realities.

quotes.topic_title: What businesses expect: value exchange and context
quotes.text: But those top-level things, those promises that have been made to the market at large, to the board, to the shareholders, those are often a great place to start for understanding what exactly your business is looking for, so you can figure out how your team's work helps contribute to success in the terms that matter most to the business.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Reframes strategy alignment: start from external commitments (board/shareholders/market promises) to guide product priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Best practices trap: sweating the middle layer
quotes.text: I think the downside of this is that there are a lot of folks who are really, really fixated on doing things the right way. And a lot of the writing and thinking about doing things the right way exists in kind of this middle layer, between impact and day-to-day work.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Names the core trap: optimizing process artifacts in the “middle layer” instead of connecting daily work to business impact.

quotes.topic_title: Best practices trap: sweating the middle layer
quotes.text: And at the end of the day, you've actually spent so much time and energy being really clever and cascading these things into these intermediate steps, that each step has incurred more and more risk that we might not achieve that impact we seek to drive.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that more cascading alignment layers can increase risk rather than reduce it.

quotes.topic_title: Best practices trap: sweating the middle layer
quotes.text: But honestly, most of the companies and teams I work with, if I ask them how their lowest-level goals add up to their highest-level goals, they look at me like I just asked them the most impossible question in the world.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A diagnostic question practitioners can use to reveal whether their OKRs/strategy actually connect to outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Best practices trap: sweating the middle layer
quotes.text: So I think there's a tendency among product teams to really sweat the middle, and to get really stressed out if the middle is not in perfect theoretical harmony with itself.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode: prioritizing internal consistency of frameworks over real-world impact.

quotes.topic_title: Best practices trap: sweating the middle layer
quotes.text: But at the end of the day, I don't think I've ever worked for a company where these things add up to a perfect breadcrumb trail you can trace back from, "We prioritized these bits of work in this sprint because it adds up to this objective, which is part of this strategy, which adds up to this initiative, which is part of this bet, which will deliver this much impact." It's just not how things work in the real world.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A memorable reality check that challenges the expectation of fully traceable alignment from sprint tasks to top-level impact.

quotes.topic_title: Low Impact PM Death Spiral explained
quotes.text: The Low Impact Death Spiral is the dynamic in which every-
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Names the core framework and pattern he’s about to unpack—how organizations systematically drift into low-impact work.

quotes.topic_title: Low Impact PM Death Spiral explained
quotes.text: The problem is if you have 10 teams adding rhinestones to a car, eventually the hood of the car is going to be so heavy that you can't lift it to get to the engine anymore, and that's exactly what happens in most product organizations.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how incremental “safe” features accumulate into complexity that blocks meaningful improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Low Impact PM Death Spiral explained
quotes.text: Low-impact work begets low-impact work. The more low-impact work you do, the harder it is to do high-impact work, the more likely you are to do low-impact work and so on and so forth.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Captures the reinforcing feedback loop practitioners can watch for and actively interrupt before it becomes irreversible.

quotes.topic_title: Low Impact PM Death Spiral explained
quotes.text: You know what? We are not going to incur the risk of being a low-impact team anymore. We are going to proactively seek out high- impact work and we're going to deliver, even if it means we have to coordinate with a lot of other teams.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Actionable stance for teams: deliberately choose higher-impact work despite coordination cost and increased scrutiny.

quotes.topic_title: Low Impact PM Death Spiral explained
quotes.text: As you just kind of alluded to, there's a big implication here of even if you are told to build a thing that the execs are really excited about, that is low impact in your opinion, that's no excuse. You're still going to get fired eventually, even though they're telling you to build it. It sucks, but that's how it goes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Contrarian warning that “executive-sponsored” low-impact work doesn’t protect teams—impact still determines outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Courage to pursue high-impact work: Mailchimp story
quotes.text: You're still going to get fired eventually, even though they're telling you to build it. It sucks, but that's how it goes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that “following orders” isn’t a shield from accountability if you’re knowingly shipping low-impact work.

quotes.topic_title: Courage to pursue high-impact work: Mailchimp story
quotes.text: She wanted a specific change in the rate of users who successfully send their first email.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A concrete example of rallying a whole org around a single core metric tied to activation and business health.

quotes.topic_title: Courage to pursue high-impact work: Mailchimp story
quotes.text: "If we mess this up, that's the entire commercial heart of the business. That's really risky."
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Captures the common fear barrier: teams avoid the highest-impact work precisely because it touches the revenue engine.

quotes.topic_title: Courage to pursue high-impact work: Mailchimp story
quotes.text: "You know what? I'm going to haunt all of you in your dreams if you do not take this on. This is the most important thing for the business."
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A memorable call-to-action that reframes cross-team ownership around what leadership says matters most.

quotes.topic_title: Courage to pursue high-impact work: Mailchimp story
quotes.text: And they did get it done, and they got it done through subtracting.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Counterintuitive product lesson: the path to impact was simplification and removing steps, not adding flashy features.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability, uncertainty, and happier commercial PMs
quotes.text: Impact is not something we can just check off a list.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A crisp mental model that reframes impact as inherently uncertain rather than a compliance exercise.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability, uncertainty, and happier commercial PMs
quotes.text: I use the word hope because again, we can do our best to influence that behavior, but we can't just check a box.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Actionable reminder to treat customer outcomes as probabilistic and focus on influence rather than certainty.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability, uncertainty, and happier commercial PMs
quotes.text: And you can follow all the best practices and have the highest velocity and do everything quote-unquote "right", but if your company goes out of business, they're not going to say, "Yeah, we're going out of business, but we're going to keep writing your paycheck for two years because all of your OKRs were a 0.6 or a 0.7."
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Contrarian warning that process excellence and OKRs don’t protect you from business reality.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability, uncertainty, and happier commercial PMs
quotes.text: The thing that surprised me most when I was researching this book is that the commercially minded PMs I interviewed were also the happiest, which I did not expect at all.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation suggesting commercial accountability can reduce stress rather than increase it.

quotes.topic_title: Accountability, uncertainty, and happier commercial PMs
quotes.text: It's like, " I work for a company. I don't get to make every decision. There are things outside of my control. I'll do the best I can, and I get to free up a little bit of energy to live the rest of my life."
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A practical mindset for sustainable accountability: focus on controllables and avoid identity-level battles over process.

quotes.topic_title: If impact bets fail: transparency and learning
quotes.text: Based on what is happening in the broader world in the market, our product, we no longer believe we are on track to hit this, but we want to adjust so that the company at large can make better predictions and resource things accordingly
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A concrete script for proactively resetting forecasts so the broader business can plan and allocate resources realistically.

quotes.topic_title: If impact bets fail: transparency and learning
quotes.text: I think you're certainly doing so much more by telling the business honestly what you think is possible and what's going to happen, as opposed to stepping back from it and saying like, "Oh, well, if we talk about it, we're going to get in trouble and nobody's going to believe us."
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Frames transparency as a higher-impact contribution than self-protective silence when bets are failing.

quotes.topic_title: If impact bets fail: transparency and learning
quotes.text: And just that simple withholding of information does its own kind of harm.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that avoiding hard conversations is not neutral—it actively damages planning and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: If impact bets fail: transparency and learning
quotes.text: if you follow the money, if you follow the decision-making, sometimes it paints a different picture.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A practical culture-diagnostic: infer real company values from incentives and decisions, not stated mission.

quotes.topic_title: Business model clarity reveals company ethics and fit
quotes.text: when you understand the business model, you understand the real world ethics and priorities of the company you work for, right?
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Frames business-model understanding as a practical way to infer a company’s true ethics and priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Business model clarity reveals company ethics and fit
quotes.text: If you understand what the company's optimizing for, what they really care about, what trade-offs and sacrifices they're willing to make in order to achieve those goals, that tells you a lot more than the mission statement.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Gives a concrete lens—optimization targets and trade-offs—to evaluate culture beyond stated values.

quotes.topic_title: Business model clarity reveals company ethics and fit
quotes.text: Which usually sounds great, but if you follow the money, if you follow the decision-making, sometimes it paints a different picture.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder to trust incentives and decisions over polished mission statements.

quotes.topic_title: Business model clarity reveals company ethics and fit
quotes.text: And I think the more you can understand how the business model works, what that value exchange is, what value is being delivered, what value is being extracted, that I think puts you in a better position to decide, if I were to help the company achieve success, do I feel good about that?
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Offers an actionable decision framework: map value delivered vs. extracted to judge whether you want to contribute to that success.

quotes.topic_title: Business model clarity reveals company ethics and fit
quotes.text: Do I feel like this is a company that if it achieves its goals has made the world a better place or not?
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A simple evaluative question to align personal ethics with the company’s incentive-driven definition of success.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break and shifting to actionable steps
quotes.text: But the other way of looking at it is that those constraints are how you do product management. Those are what guides you to the commercial decisions you should be making.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Reframes constraints from blockers into the core inputs that should shape product decision-making.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break and shifting to actionable steps
quotes.text: If you can really understand those constraints, figure out how to work well within them, that's a huge commercial advantage for your business.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Actionable advice: treat deep constraint understanding as a competitive advantage rather than a limitation.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break and shifting to actionable steps
quotes.text: Similarly, if your company has quarterly financial targets to hit, congratulations, you know what the business really cares about.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing that makes business pressure a clarity tool for prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break and shifting to actionable steps
quotes.text: You don't necessarily need to cascade that 10 different levels into 45 OKRs if you can do work that you know feeds directly into what the company cares about the most.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Practical prioritization heuristic: skip excessive OKR decomposition when you can tie work directly to top business goals.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break and shifting to actionable steps
quotes.text: What I'm actually saying is that the things you think you're fighting against are usually the things that are giving your work shape, if you let them be.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Memorable mental model: stop battling constraints and instead let them define the boundaries that enable effective action.

quotes.topic_title: Three steps preview: start with team goals
quotes.text: What I'm actually saying is that the things you think you're fighting against are usually the things that are giving your work shape, if you let them be.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframing: constraints and organizational forces can be used as productive structure rather than treated only as blockers.

quotes.topic_title: Three steps preview: start with team goals
quotes.text: Yeah, so the first step, and I think the most important and where a lot of my work plays out is in setting team goals, close to company goals.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: Introduces the first step of an impact-first approach: align team goals tightly with company goals to drive meaningful outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Three steps preview: start with team goals
quotes.text: No more than one step away from company goals.
quotes.speaker: Matt LeMay
quotes.context: A concrete alignment rule teams can apply immediately to keep goals from drifting into disconnected proxy metrics.
